docs.title: Introduction & Overview
docs.text: Welcome to our comprehensive guide on Obsidian, a powerful note-taking application. This guide will help you get started with Obsidian and show you how to leverage its features for effective note organization.

docs.title: What is Obsidian?
docs.text: Obsidian is a note-taking application that allows you to organize your notes locally on your computer. It uses a system of interconnected markdown files to create a powerful knowledge base.

docs.title: Why use Obsidian?
docs.text:
• Fast and responsive interface
  • Clean, distinction-free writing enviroment
  • Strong community support and plugins
  • Powerful linking capabilities between notes

docs.title: What this guide will cover?
docs.text: In the first part of this documentation, we'll get you started with the bascis of Obsidian. Then, we'll explore how to implement the Zettelkasten method using Obsidian, which will serve as a "personal writing assistant" to help you organize notes more efficiently and connect ideas to deepen your understanding of any subject.

docs.title: Who is This Guide For?
docs.text: Intended Audience Description Writers Improve note-taking for research and content creation. Students Organize study materials and enhance learning. Teachers Structure lesson plans and resources effectively. Professors Manage academic research and references. Knowledge Enthusiasts Anyone interested in better knowledge management.

docs.title: Basic Note-taking in Obsidian
docs.text: Let's start with the basics. This section assumes you have already installed Obsidian on your device.

docs.title: Creating a Vault
docs.text:
A vault is a folder that contains all your notes and attachments in Obsidian

  1. Click on "Obsidian Vault" in the bottom left corner o the application
  2. Select "Manage Vaults"
  3. Click the purple "Create" button
  4. Name your vualt (e.g., "123")
  5. Click "Browse" to select a location (e.g., your desktop)
  6. Click the purple "Create" button

Note: A vault is simply a folder on your computer that will store all your notes locally. Everything you write will be kept inside this folder.

docs.title: Customizing Appearance
docs.text:
You can customize the look and feel of Obsidian to suit your preference.

  1. Click the settings icon (gear) in the bottom left corner
  2. Go to "Appearance"
  3. Under "Themes," click on "Minimal"
  4. Click "Install and Use"

docs.title: Changing Fonts
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Select "Appearance"
  3. Scroll to "Fonts"
  4. Choose your preferred font

docs.title: Creating your First Note
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl+O (or Cmd+O on Mac)
  2. Type a name for your note (e.g., "abc")
  3. Press Enter
  4. Start writing your content (e.g., "This is a test")

docs.title: Adding Images to Notes
docs.text:
You can easily add images to your notes by dragging and dropping.

Simply drag an image file (e.g., "Lake.jpg") from your desktop into your note.

docs.title: Creating Folders
docs.text:
Organizing your notes with folders helps keep your vault tidy.

  1. Right-click in the empty space of the left sidebar
  2. Select "New Folder"
  3. Name your folder (e.g., "Assets")
  4. Drag files into your new folder as needed

docs.title: Setting Up Automatic File Organization
docs.text:
You can configure Obsidian to automatically place new attachments in a specific folder.

  1. Go to Settings
  2. Select "Files & Links"
  3. Under "Default location for new attachments," select "Vault folder in the folder specified below"
  4. In "Attachment folder path," enter your folder name (e.g., "Assets")

Now any new images you add will automatically be stored in the Assets folder.

docs.title: Linking Images in Notes
docs.text: You can link images stored in your vault by tapping the exclamation mark and then tapping the left suqare bracket "[" twice then write the title of the specific attachment you want to show.

docs.title: Creating and Editing Notes
docs.text: syntax Using Markdown syntax Headings # Heading 1 ## Heading 2 Bold Text **Bold text** Italic Text *Italic text* Bullet List - Bullet List Numbered List 1. Numbered List Auto-save Notes are automatically saved.

docs.title: Linking Notes
docs.text:
You can link notes using double brackets:

[[Note Title]]

This creates a connection between notes.

docs.title: Using Callouts
docs.text:
If you want to make specific text or a paragraph in your notes stand out, use callout blocks in Obsidian.

  1. Open a page and use the /Insert callout command.
  2. Callout command is >[!tip]
  3. Add Tip, Warning, or Note to denote a callout.
  4. Insert a Title and content.
  5. Hit Enter to view your callout block in your notes.

Example of the Code for Callout:

>[!tip]
> Here's a callout block.
> It supports **Markdown**

docs.title: Graph View
docs.text: Action Description Open Graph View Click on Graph View in the sidebar. Explore Connections Interactively view links between different notes.

docs.text: Feature Description Core & Community Plugins Obsidian offers both core and community plugins. Access Plugins Navigate to Settings > Community Plugins. Install Plugins Browse and install plugins to extend functionality. Customize Themes Modify themes under Settings > Appearance.

docs.title: The Zettelkasten Method for Beginners
docs.text: Now let's explore how to implement the Zettelkasten method in Obsidian to create a powerful knowledge management system.

docs.title: What is the Zettelkasten Method?
docs.text: Inspired by "How to Take Smart Notes" by Sonke Ahrens, the Zettelkasten is a slip-box system that clusters ideas and connects them to create new links as you continue learning.

docs.title: Three Major Benefits
docs.text:
1. Great for learning
  2. Encourages slow, deliberate learning that boosts memory
  3. Provides instant feedback on your understanding

  4. Gives freedom to connect ideas

  5. Stores and mixes ideas

  6. Notes are free to mingle and connect with each other

  7. Faster and easier writing

  8. Acts as a personal writing assistant

docs.title: Setting Up Your Zettelkasten
docs.text:
1. Create a new vault named "The Zettelkasten"
  2. Set the location to your desktop
  3. Remove any clutter to start with a clean workspace

docs.title: Creating the Folder Structure
docs.text:
Create the following six folders by right-clicking on the empty space in the left sidebar and selecting "New Folder":

  1. 1 - Rough Notes: For temporary ideas, reminders, and undeveloped thoughts
  2. 2 - Source Material: For insights from content you consume
  3. 3 - Tags: To help navigate your network of notes
  4. 4 - Indexes: For tags that have grown significantly
  5. 5 - Template: To store your notes templates
  6. 6 - Main Notes: For your primary, well-developed notes

docs.title: Setting Up Source Material Subfolders
docs.text: Within the "2 - Source Material" folder, create subfolders to categorize your sources: - Videos - Readings - (You can add more categories as needed)

docs.title: Understanding Tags and Indexes
docs.text:
The Tags folder helps you navigate your network of notes. When you have multiple notes related to a specific topic, you can tag them using double square brackets, like [[TypeScript]].

When a tag connects to 15 or more notes, consider moving it to the Indexes folder to better organize your knowledge network.

docs.title: Setting Default Location for New Notes
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Select "Files & Links"
  3. Under "Default location for new notes," select "6 - Main Notes"

Now all new notes you create will automatically be placed in the Main Notes folder.

docs.title: Creating a Template
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl+O to create a new note
  2. Name it "Template"
  3. Drag this file to the "5 - Template" folder
  4. Add the following content to your template:
Title: Template

Created: {{date}} {{time}}

##### Status:  #baby
<!-- Indicate how developed this note is --> 
<!-- Use #baby for basic initial thoughts --> 
<!-- Use #child for somewhat developed ideas --> 
<!-- Use #adult for well-developed concepts -->
<!-- Use #quote if this note contains direct quotes -->

##### Tags: 
<!-- Add 2-5 relevant tags that help categorize this note --> 
<!-- Use double brackets to create links: [[creativity]] [[psychology]] etc. --> 
<!-- Choose tags that aren't too broad or too specific --> 

### Main Content

<!-- Write your thoughts, analysis, and insights here -->
<!-- Focus on ONE clear idea per note --> 
<!-- Aim for clarity and brevity (under 500 words) -->
<!-- Use your own words to demonstrate understanding -->
<!-- This is where the real value of your note system lives -->


### References

<!-- Link to related notes and source materials --> 
<!-- Example: [[How creativity works]] --> 
<!-- For source materials, link to your source notes folder --> 
<!-- Example: [[2 - Source Material/Book - How to Take Smart Notes]] -->

### Connections

<!-- Describe how this note connects to other ideas --> 
<!-- This helps build your network of knowledge --> 
<!-- Example: This connects to my note on [[deliberate practice]] because... →

docs.title: Setting Up Template Hotkey
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Enable the "Templates" core plugin
  3. Go to "Hotkeys"
  4. Search for "Templates"
  5. Click the plus sign next to "Templates: Insert Template"
  6. Press Ctrl+R to set this as your hotkey

docs.title: Adding Essential Community Plugins
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Select "Community Plugins" and enable them
  3. Browse and install these two plugins:
  4. Better Word Count
  5. Smart Random Note

docs.title: Testing Your New Zettelkasten System
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl+O to create a new note
  2. Name it "Test Note" and press Enter
  3. Press Ctrl+R to insert your template
  4. Fill in the template with your content

Congratualtions! You've successfully set up your Zettelkasten system in Obsidian.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: If you've followed these steps correctly, you should now have a functioning Zettelkasten system in Obsidian. Your notes will automatically be organized in the appropriate folders, and you can use the template to create consistent, well-structured notes. Next, try creating a few notes on related topics to see how the connections feature works.

docs.title: Practical Use of Zettelkasten in Obsidian
docs.text: After setting up the Zettelkasten system in Obsidian, this guide will help us explore how to use it in practical, everyday situations. This guide focuses on simple workflows that you can implement right away without overwhelming complexity.

docs.title: Morning Capture (5-10 minutes)
docs.text:
Start your day by creating a daily note to capture initial thoughts:

  1. Press Ctrl+O (or Cmd+O on Mac)
  2. Type "Daily Note” then press Ctrl+R
  3. Jot down:
  4. Tasks for the day
  5. Questions that came to mind overnight
  6. Ideas you want to explore

Tip: Keep this quick and informal. The goal is to capture thoughts, not organize them yet.

docs.title: Throughout the Day: Capture Fleeting Notes
docs.text:
When you encounter interesting ideas during the day:

  1. Open Obsidian
  2. Create a new note in your "1 - Rough Notes" folder
  3. Write down the idea quickly
  4. Add a simple tag like #idea or #question
  5. Don't worry about formatting or connections yet

Example of a fleeting note:

Idea about project management I wonder if the Pomodoro technique could be combined with Kanban boards for better productivity tracking. [[idea]] [[productivity]]

docs.title: Evening Processing (15-20 minutes)
docs.text:
At the end of the day, process your fleeting notes:

  1. Open your "1 - Rough Notes" folder
  2. For each note that seems valuable:
  3. Create a permanent note in your "6 - Main Notes" folder
  4. Give it a clear, specific title
  5. Develop the idea more fully
  6. Add connections to existing notes
  7. Archive or delete processed fleeting notes

docs.title: Practical Tagging Approach
docs.text: Keep your tagging system simple but effective:

docs.title: Three Essential Tag Types
docs.text:
1. Topic Tags: What the note is about

  2. Examples: #programming, #writing, #cooking

  3. Type Tags: What kind of note it is

  4. Examples: #idea, #question, #concept, #quote

  5. Status Tags: The development stage of the note

  6. Examples: #baby (initial thoughts), #child (partially developed), #adult (well-developed)

Note: Start with just a few tags and add more only when needed. Too many tags can become overwhelming.

docs.title: Reading and Research Workflow
docs.text: When reading books, articles, or watching educational content:

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Source Note
docs.text:
1. Create a note in your "2 - Source Material" folder
  2. Name it with the source and title (e.g., "Book - Atomic Habits")
  3. Include basic information:
  4. Author
  5. Publication date
  6. Where you found it
  7. Key topics

docs.title: Step 2: Take Smart Notes While Consuming
docs.text:
As you read or watch:

  1. Pause when you encounter an interesting idea
  2. In your source note, write a brief summary in your own words
  3. Add page numbers or timestamps for reference
  4. Mark particularly insightful points with a symbol like "⭐"

docs.title: Step 3: Process Into Permanent Notes
docs.text:
After finishing the source material:

  1. Review your source note
  2. For each key insight, create a permanent note
  3. Focus on one idea per note
  4. Connect to existing notes in your system

docs.title: Example 1: Learning a New Programming Language
docs.text:
Let's say you're learning Python:

  1. Create a source note for each tutorial or documentation you read
  2. Create permanent notes for specific concepts:
  3. "Python List Comprehensions"
  4. "Python Dictionary Methods"
  5. "Error Handling in Python"
  6. Connect these notes to broader programming concepts you already have
  7. Create a "Python MOC" (Map of Content) that links to all your Python notes

docs.title: Example 2: Writing a Research Paper
docs.text:
When working on a research paper:

  1. Create source notes for each reference
  2. Create permanent notes for individual arguments or evidence
  3. Use a project note to outline your paper structure
  4. Link to relevant permanent notes under each section of your outline

docs.title: Planning a Project
docs.text:
1. Create a project note in your "6 - Main Notes" folder
  2. Name it with the project name (e.g., "Website Redesign Project")
  3. Outline the main components of the project
  4. Search your Zettelkasten for relevant notes
  5. Link to these notes in your project outline

docs.title: Writing Using Your Zettelkasten
docs.text:
When writing an article or essay:

  1. Create an outline note
  2. Search for relevant notes in your system
  3. Link to these notes under appropriate sections
  4. Use these linked notes as "building blocks" for your writing
  5. Expand on the ideas from your notes to create your draft

Tip: Your Zettelkasten becomes more valuable as a writing assistant the more you use it.

docs.title: Weekly Maintenance (30 minutes)
docs.text:
Once a week, spend time maintaining your Zettelkasten:

  1. Review recent notes and improve connections
  2. Look for notes that could be merged or split
  3. Update your Maps of Content with new notes
  4. Explore your graph view to discover unexpected connections
  5. Identify and develop notes tagged as #baby or #child

docs.title: "I have too many disconnected notes"
docs.text: Solution: Set aside 15 minutes to: 1. Use the graph view to find isolated notes 2. For each note, ask "What other ideas does this connect to?" 3. Add at least one connection to another note

docs.title: "I'm not sure if I should create a new note or add to an existing one"
docs.text: Solution: Follow this rule of thumb: 1. If the idea can stand alone as a concept, create a new note 2. If it's an extension or example of an existing note, add to that note 3. When in doubt, create a new note - it's easier to combine later than to separate

docs.title: "I'm spending too much time organizing and not enough thinking"
docs.text: Solution: 1. Set time limits for processing notes (e.g., 20 minutes) 2. Focus on content first, organization second 3. Remember that connections are more important than perfect organization

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Your Zettelkasten is a tool for thinking, not just storage. The true value emerges when you:

  1. Capture ideas consistently
  2. Process them thoughtfully
  3. Connect them meaningfully
  4. Use them in your creative work

Start simple, be consistent, and your Zettelkasten will gradually become an invaluable thinking partner that helps you develop ideas and create better work.

Remember: The perfect Zettelkasten is not the most organized one, but the one you actually use every day.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Problem Solution Obsidian won't open my vault Check if the vault folder still exists at the specified location Images aren't displaying in notes Verify the image path is correct and the file exists in your vault Template hotkey isn't working Make sure the Templates core plugin is enabled in Settings Notes aren't appearing in graph view Check if your notes contain any links to other notes Text formatting isn't appearing correctly Ensure you're using proper Markdown syntax

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Term Definition Vault A folder on your computer that contains all your Obsidian notes and settings Markdown A lightweight markup language used to format text in Obsidian Zettelkasten A note-taking and knowledge management method that focuses on connecting ideas Backlinks References that show which notes link to the current note MOC Map of Content; a note that serves as a table of contents for a topic
